In the case of the mining industry, Nabalco is the major user of fuel oil in its bauxite mine and aluminium refinery at Gove in the Northern Territory. Nabalco faced an increase of its fuel oil tax bill to $30 million per year, which would place a severe constraint on Nabalco's competitiveness.

For the coastal shipping industry, the 1993 petroleum products excise increases had a particularly severe impact, adding almost $10 million per year in cost to the industry as a whole, or an average cost of $290,000 per vessel per year. The last round of reform measures in that industry, which saw crew levels reduced to an average of 18.5 crew per vessel, delivered savings of an average of $217,000 per vessel per year, which would have been hopelessly negated by the fuel excise increases.

While the coalition would like to see the government commit to reducing the absurd petrol and diesel excise for road users, this does not diminish our support for the reductions encompassed in this particular bill. It is highly appropriate and timely to debate these matters today as petrol and diesel excise rose yesterday by some 0.5c per litre in line with the government's tax by stealth policy of six-monthly increases in excise based on the consumer price index.

Mr Deputy Speaker, did you know that from yesterday your constituents are paying 0.5c more per litre in petrol excise? I know you will be distressed by that, as we in the coalition parties are. Thus, motorists will be hit with increased fuel bills from today onwards, while householders can expect the cost of essential goods to rise. As usual, the price increases will be worse for rural businesses and households because of the transport costs involved.

While 0.5c per litre may not seem much, past increases have brought the excise from 6c per litre, when the Labor government took office in March 1983, to its staggering level of almost 35c per litre for leaded petrol. Worse, while the excise brings in nearly $10 billion per year, only eight per cent of the total fuel excise take is returned to road funding as was originally planned. Quite simply, many businesses have no option but to rely on motor transport for their livelihood and must pay any increase in price or face collapse.

Households throughout Australia, particularly in rural areas, buy essential goods such as food and clothing which have been transported long distances by road and will cost more as a result of this excise increase. One only has to ask truckies or contractors what they think of the petrol and diesel fuel excise. They know they have no choice but to travel long distances to service rural communities and that those petrol excises just cascade through the whole price structure so that the ordinary household buying everyday grocery items is forced to pay more.

There is no defence from government, and I do not believe the government will even mount a defence, because of its deficit problems, its mismanagement of the economy and its blow-out in the budget deficit. It is dependent on this business input cost.

I turn now to excise tariff proposal No. 3 of 1994, which proposes a decrease in the excise duty payable on aviation gasoline, known as avgas, of 6.327c per litre, and an increase in the excise duty payable on aviation kerosene, known as avtur, of 1.194c per litre. The excise variations took effect from 1 July 1994 but were announced in the 1994-95 budget.

Avgas is the fuel used in piston driven propeller aircraft, while avtur is used in jet aircraft and turbine powered propeller aircraft. The proposed decrease in excise on avgas and avtur actually consists of an increase in the air safety regulation duty on avgas and avtur of 1.194c per litre and a decrease of 7.521c per litre in the component of the avgas excise associated with the Civil Aviation Authority's airways services. The net change in the duty on avgas is therefore a decrease of 6.327c per litre.

The airways services referred to are provided by the CAA and are funded by charges on avtur aircraft and by a portion of the avgas excise. Over recent years, the CAA has substantially reduced its expenditure on delivering these services, primarily by consolidating its operations. For instance, the efficiency measures adopted include closing the Mount Isa and Karratha control towers and withdrawing flight service functions to major centres.

The reduction in the duty on avgas passes on some of those savings to the general aviation sector, which largely uses avgas powered aircraft. However, avtur operators have already received significant benefits from the CAA's cost reduction program, with the CAA reducing its airways charges by $90 million in the 1992-93 financial year and $109 million in the 1993-94 year.

The CAA recommended the duty decrease to the government following a revision of its cost recovery arrangements. The new duty rate is based on the principle that avgas operators should be required to cover only the direct cost of the services provided to them—a genuine user pays arrangement. Many of the CAA's expenses, such as the cost of providing air traffic services, would have to be incurred regardless of whether they were used by avgas operators. These measures will have a neutral financial impact, with the duty alterations balanced by equivalent changes in the funds appropriated to the CAA.

Excise tariff proposal No. 4 of 1994 retained excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil and condensate for use as a fuel other than when used as a fuel in the recovery, production, transportation or refining of stabilised crude oil or condensate. In 1993 the government legislated to end the practice of fuel substitution to avoid payment of excise as, reportedly, crude oil and condensates were being sold directly to consumers by producers as substitutes of petrol and diesel. However, in attempting to end this fuel substitution, the government inadvertently allowed crude oil and condensates used in the recovery, production, transportation and refining of crude oil or condensates to be subject to excise. This anomaly is now corrected as a result of this legislation.

Although this seems straightforward, the amendment imposes a burden on producers in collecting small amounts of excise. I therefore seek an assurance from the government that it will balance the needs of compliance with the costs that must be borne by the producers in meeting the legal and administrative requirements of excise collection. This is a very important point, and I would wish for the parliamentary secretary addressing his mind to it.

I mention one further relevant issue involving taxation on petroleum products before concluding my remarks. In recent months it has become common knowledge—it has been confirmed in the last 48 hours by the Treasurer (Mr Willis)—that the government is considering the imposition of a carbon or energy tax to help meet its perceived commitments to reduce greenhouse gases under the United Nations framework convention on climate change. Such a tax would be levied, according to government sources, on the amount of carbon dioxide emitted from an industrial process so that the price of commodities, such as petrol, coal, electricity and aluminium, would all increase.

While initially enormous rates of taxation were proposed, especially by the green movement, a recognition of the significant damage this would cause to industry, and the economy, has seen the proposals modified to a proposed tax of $1.25 per tonne of emitted carbon dioxide with exports exempted. That is the proposal that I am quite certain is before the government at present. All indications are that, at this time at least, the government will accept that idea of $1.25 carbon tax per tonne of emitted carbon dioxide.

While seemingly modest, in effect, this tax is still fundamentally flawed for several reasons. Greenhouse gas reduction is a global problem and must be resolved at a global level. It is also fundamentally an issue of trade competitiveness. Australia must be very careful not to throw away the competitive advantage we hold in having abundant natural resources simply to appear greener than green.

For a rate of $1.25 per tonne of carbon dioxide, the tax has been estimated by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research to yield greenhouse gas savings of only three per cent off the government's target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000. Yet, even at this rate, the tax would have a significant and vital effect on our most important industries and consumers at large. For example, the Business Council of Australia has estimated that the tax would add 20 per cent to the cost of brown coal and 10 per cent to the cost of black coal. This, in turn, would quickly appear in increased electricity prices which inevitably impact hardest on the least well off in the community, including pensioners and the unemployed. The loss of jobs, competitiveness and investment that would result from a carbon tax would in no measure be compensated for by the $320 million revenue raised each year by this $1.25 carbon tax.

As I have argued repeatedly in this place, the key to improving Australia's greenhouse gas emission performance is to institute an effective program of energy efficiency improvements throughout the industrial, government and residential sectors. The government has completely failed in this regard, as highlighted by the Auditor-General nearly two years ago in his review of the energy management programs administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Increased energy efficiency will save money as well as improving greenhouse performance but the government must institute sensible educational and incentive programs and lead the way by example. The opposition supports the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to participate in this debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. Amendments of this kind are of great importance, not necessarily in their particular detail but in their general significance. I am pleased to have this opportunity to support my good friend and colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay).

PARA.TAB: Before I deal with some of the more technical details that the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) dealt with in leading for the opposition, there are a couple of general matters that I would like to take up in connection with some of his observations. It is quite reasonable that he should, as he did, use this piece of rather technical and precise legislation as a vehicle to draw the attention of the parliament and the community to other concerns which the opposition has in connection with the question of excise duties. In particular, I know he spoke at some length on the question of petrol excise and what is happening with petrol prices at the present time.

I thank him for the elucidation which he brought to the technical content of this legislation. I was interested to hear those observations and some of the explanations which he provided. That followed the very comprehensive second reading speech by the parliamentary secretary.

The member for Gippsland challenged the government to improve the efficiency with which adjustments are made. That is an interesting suggestion. I would be delighted to know how further significant improvement could be brought about in making these technical adjustments because, as all other members of the parliament know, these amendments were announced during the budget early last year and operated from midnight of that day.

The honourable member referred to the extensive debate that has taken place since then before this legislation came in here for a second reading debate. To my mind no such debate has taken place. I do not think the honourable member for Gippsland could draw my attention to any significant evidence of widespread debate out there in the community about these precise elements. Debate has taken place within the industry, certainly, but I will guarantee that the honourable member's electorate office was not inundated with people out there in the electorate—his constituents—saying, `When will this legislation to confirm the budget provisions for these arrangements which are already in existence and operating come through the parliament? We are waiting with bated breath.'

I doubt very much the extent of the debate that the honourable member for Gippsland has been suggesting. In fact, the parliamentary secretary draws my attention to the fact that we are incorporating those amendments now in the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

There were some other interesting comments that the honourable member for Gippsland made as well. I would like to emphasise that this legislation, as he knows and as everyone else would acknowledge, is essentially technical in nature. It introduces the precision of those proposed changes in excise duty which have been introduced for the reasons which have been indicated by the parliamentary secretary in his speech and have been alluded to as well by the honourable member for Gippsland.

I want to make mention as well of one of these continuing furphies, one of these shibboleths, one of these rural myths which continue to be advanced by members of the coalition and will continue to be advanced by members of the coalition until that time on the distant horizon when, God forbid, they may become the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even from the grave.

—Even from the grave, as the parliamentary secretary suggests. I want to mention that urban myth. I say members of the coalition will continue to advance this argument until they become government and then they will cease doing it and we will start. Let me give you that assurance.

PARA.TAB: I am keeping a file on all of the observations that the honourable member for Gippsland has made about petrol excise, the way in which it has increased, and the proportion of it which is being applied to road construction. I am keeping a file and I am going to repeat that. I am going to say that this is not my argument—if I am still in the parliament when the opposition comes into government, but I do not think I will be. Talking about us being interred at some time in the future, I do not think I will be around at that time.

But when opposition members do, they will have to decide on what basis they will make their road funding arrangements. We went through a stage in defining the road funding arrangements where we took a proportion, as you will recall, of fuel excise and we called it a road user charge. We always fixed that road user charge at a level which was just sufficient to provide the funds that we had decided we would put into road construction and road maintenance at a Commonwealth level. We would set the road user charge out of petrol excise in order to fund whatever we needed.

I did not think that that was a very sensible arrangement. It did not really serve any purpose. I suppose, in a sense, it just helped to reinforce the idea that petrol excise was being collected to fund roads. That is not the way to do it. Petrol excise, like other types of revenue, is a source of general revenue. When we get the whole bucket of funds together, we ask, `What is the relative importance of our commitment to roads? What proportion of that big bucket of revenue should go to roads?', and just allocate it.

The honourable member for Gippsland is the main opposition spokesman on this matter. I would suggest that, if he has any confidence or optimism about the prospect of the coalition in future, he will start now to move away from that position, because I have a file on those statements that he has been making from time to time. If he starts to move away from that position I will give him a guarantee. As soon as he starts to move away from that position, I ask him to draw my attention to it—if I miss it—and send me a copy of those comments so that I can add them to my file. That will help me to qualify the statements that he has been making in the past.

What the opposition says about the increase in excise—6c a litre in 1983 up to about 34c a litre at the present time—is true, but our excise imposition on petrol is still one of the lowest in the OECD. The price at which we sell petrol in Australia is one of the lowest in the OECD. Commonwealth road funding has contracted back to concentrate on the national highway system for both maintenance and construction. There has been a very significant level of commitment—and there is continuing commitment—on the part of the Commonwealth in an area which, constitutionally and traditionally, was essentially the responsibility of state governments.

I do not want to spend much more time on this, but if the opposition suggests that money taken from road users should all go back into the roads it will find itself in an absurd situation. The natural extension of that is that all the money we take from the beer drinkers should go back into pubs, breweries, hop farms and research into improving the quality of beer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the drinkers.

—The drinkers would probably say yes. The same applies to tobacco. Really, that whole idea is silly. These excise provisions are essentially general revenue provisions. If we were to take that 34c a litre off petrol, the results would be catastrophic. It would be absurd; it would be silly. Even the opposition would not suggest that we should do that. If the whole of that 34c per litre from petrol were to go back into road construction, we would not be able to spend the money.

PARA.TAB: The parliamentary secretary has very kindly drawn to my attention the fact that the state of the roads became so bad under the Fraser government that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Fund was introduced in order to increase the volume of funds going into the maintenance of roads. The parliamentary secretary's observation about the deplorable state of the road system in Australia, which we inherited in 1983, is spot on. The system was falling apart. It then became necessary for the Labor government, which has been in office since 1983, to make sure that the funds were found and appropriately applied.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill, as I suggested earlier, represents some precise and technical adjustments to the exact levels of those excise duties on the particular items that are referred to in this amendment, for the reasons that have been given. It also represents the general process of the continuous refinement of the excise provisions for a whole number of reasons and, of course, there are some specific purposes which are related to these.

The first amendment is the excise tariff proposal No. 2 and, as I indicated before, these announcements were made at the time of the budget last year. They applied from 12 o'clock on budget night and they have continued to apply. All we are doing really is following the matter up and giving it the appropriate legislative base. The decreases operating under proposal No. 2 are in response to representations from industry that the increase in fuel oil has had a significant impact on input costs of certain industries, particularly export oriented mining and mineral processing operations and the coastal shipping industry.

When we are talking about the purposes of these types of arrangements and the way in which government should apply them, an essential element would be having a government which shows itself to be responsive to industry and listens to industry. Of course, that is the reason why these particular adjustments have been introduced. Kerosene is also used as an input by certain manufacturing operations and heating oil currently competes with a range of excise free products such as natural gas. The Australian Customs Service advised the government that the excise duty on topped crude oil should be decreased and realigned with the excise duty on fuel oil. These products are similar and sometimes identical in specifications and topped crude oil can be used as a substitute for fuel oil. Previously that 1c per litre differential was resulting in that substitution effect taking place. So what we have done now is to equalise them, and I suppose that is a contribution to that level playing field.

The second one is the excise tariff proposal No. 3. Those changes have been brought about as a result of the contribution of the airline industry to safety regulation, and the decrease in excise duty on avgas should be viewed in the context of the significant savings that the Civil Aviation Authority has delivered to the industry. I say in this context that the airways charges, for example, were reduced by $109 million in 1993-94 and an estimated $56 million in 1994-95 in real terms.

Those reductions have been taking place. Excise duties of this kind are often used and are being used for cost recovery purposes. When there are cost adjustments, a responsive government will respond and adjust the excise, which is based on the cost. That is what this exercise is all about. Again the parliamentary secretary kindly brings to my attention the fact that in this connection the financial impact of that particular provision is neutral, which simply confirms the point that I am making. It is a cost recovery provision. Costs have reduced, excise is reduced and the overall impact is neutral.

Excise tariff proposal No. 4 is directly associated with amendments contained in the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1993. Those two acts introduce measures to address revenue erosion resulting from the substitution of stabilised crude petroleum oil and condensate for other petroleum products attracting a higher rate of excise duty. It is always a question of refinement: increasing the extent to which governments respond to the purposes for which the duties are imposed and the way in which those duties at any particular level are impacting on the people who are most affected.

The evidence is there that the government has been responding to industry submission, which indicates that those types of approaches—quite legitimate and, to my mind, necessary approaches—have been more than adequately followed by the government. I quote briefly from the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech. When referring to excise tariff proposal No. 3, he said that the per litre increase is a continuation of the phase-in arrangements for cost recovery with respect to air safety regulation by the Civil Aviation Authority. That emphasis on cost recovery is apparent in the parliamentary secretary's comment.
I said that the announcements were first made in the budget of last year. In the budget speech the Treasurer (Mr Willis) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Excise on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene will be reduced by almost 2c per litre from tonight.
It was, and it applied from then, and we are just giving legislative effect to those budget announcements, which have operated since then. He went on to say:
The reduction in fuel oil excise will provide significant benefits to coastal shipping and export oriented mineral projects.

Of course, to a large extent those adjustments were made as a result of representations that were made by those industries. That statement was filled out in Budget Paper No. 1 in these terms, which I quote for precision:
Customs and excise rates on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene will decrease by 1.9777 cents per litre to 6.586 cents per litre from midnight on 10 May 1994.
That was the night on which the budget was delivered, as I have indicated. The paragraph continued:

This adjustment will better align the increase in excise on these products with the increase in excise on unleaded petrol arising from the 1993-94 Budget measures. To provide greater consistency in the tax treatment of substitutable fuel products, customs and excise rates on topped crude for use otherwise than as a refinery feedstock will decrease by 2.9777 cents per litre to 6.586 cents per litre from midnight on 10 May 1994.

So there has been a realignment of those excise duties available to make sure that there is no artificial substitution effect, which is inherent in differential excises which relate to products which can be substituted one for another. It has been apparent that the excise on petroleum products, including those with which this legislation is essentially concerned, is imposed at a fixed rate per litre of the product.

PARA.TAB: Excise and customs are important in the whole area of government policy making, not just in a revenue sense, because in that area it is becoming relatively less and less important in each of the excises except the more traditional ones—on petrol, on tobacco and on alcohol. Even in those areas it is not just a revenue consideration; there are important social, health and general government policy considerations as well. An appropriate price for petrol helps to ensure the conservation of a finite reserve and its more efficient use; the imposition of excise on tobacco and alcohol, hopefully, assists in reducing the consumption of both of them. Governments have to refine all of these areas from time to time, and we do so, in order to achieve the general objectives of government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has outlined very well the effect of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and made some general points. The coalition is supporting the bill. Perhaps I should just touch on a couple of points that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) made.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about the OECD levels of excise we must remember that Australia is unique. Australia has this vast land mass and any impact that fuel excise has on our regional economy, particularly, can have quite significant effects. The honourable member for Gippsland touched on that cascading effect, which I think is too often ignored. It is too typical of the centralism of Canberra governments, and particularly this Canberra Labor government, that it ignores the needs of regional Australia.

I was particularly interested in comments by the honourable member for Charlton about the fact that excise really is not about collecting money for roads; it is about collecting revenue. I think that is a very honest presentation of the facts—it is not about collecting money for roads, it is just another form of taxation. But, in that honesty, the honourable member informs all of Australia that the government has ignored the effect particularly on the domestic regional economy. I have already made the point that Australia has a large landmass and this cascading effect of excise has an overwhelming impact. I remember that one of the first acts of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he was Treasurer, was to abolish the fuel equalisation program. There was an ethic in this country that fuel prices should be almost the same whether you lived in a metropolitan or a regional area. In one sweep of the pen, in about 1983-84, the then Treasurer abolished that mechanism. I think that indicates the convenience that from then on the government found in collecting general revenue from excise.

I refer back to the comments made by the two previous speakers that it was 6c added when Labor came in and now it is 34c. Somewhere in that period, I think towards the late 1980s, we had also an IPP—import parity pricing—mechanism. I remember all the comments then about world competitiveness, how exporters in particular had to be competitive, and how if the price of crude went up we would expect to pay through the IPP and if the price of crude went down we might pay through the IPP. But it did not happen like that. What happened was that when the price of crude collapsed on the world market we said, `We cannot do without the revenue,' which the honourable member acknowledged, and we transferred across to excise. I think that is the danger we run into when we talk about excise as a simple general revenue raiser.

Looking at excise in some detail, I will give the South Australian experience. There we have the federal tax of currently 34c on leaded. If you live in the city or within 50 kilometres of Adelaide, you pay another 9c, which brings you out at 41c for tax collections, federal and state, on a litre of fuel. The RAA, the automobile association of that state, has produced some figures. It makes the comment that the excise that is charged on this commodity is something like four times the luxury tax rate. I keep reiterating the point that Australia is unique. The Europeans may do things in a particular way; somebody else may do them in a particular way. But the fact that fuel is a convenient tax raiser does not necessarily mean that fuel excise reflects the best interests of Australia.

Another little technique that the government tried on—it did not get away with it on this whole fuel business—back in 1993 was a diesel fuel levy, a $10 million fee for administering the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Thanks to the vigilance of the Senate, it was found to be unconstitutional. The minister, Senator Schacht, was embarrassed to find that it was actually unconstitutional. These are the sorts of habits that governments get into. They get into this convenient habit of collecting revenue—I suppose I could go on at some length about the expenditure and the priorities of government—and the convenient mechanism of excise.

Of course the coalition is supporting the amendments outlined in the bill we are debating this morning and we welcome the modest decreases. But I would make a point about the decreases, in relation to fuel oil in particular, which affect the mining and shipping industries, et cetera: why in the blazes did we have the increase in the first place if we were fair dinkum about assessing world competitiveness? The member for Charlton would have us believe that we listened to people in industry, we went back to them, we talked to them and reduced the amount. Why in the blazes did the government not talk to them before it actually raised the amounts?

I think this is the issue. If there was an ongoing consultative process with industry, understanding the true competitive requirement for export industry, the government would have consulted before it raised the amount, collected the revenue and then at 10 minutes past midnight said, `Oh, that was a bit high; that was a bit rough.' As I recall it, it wiped out in one hit the benefits of some of the efficiencies that the shipping industry had been trying to make. When the industry came and said, `This is what you have done,' the government said, `Oh, sorry, we need to alter that. We realise now that we have cut across your efforts to improve your industry.' Why would the government not consult first and have a look at it. Then, if there was a capacity to pay, maybe there would be some case. But, no, it raises the amount and then it drops it. That is the criticism I have to make this morning.

In recent weeks I have done some work on the question of the carbon tax. Obviously, it has been a point of general interest. In my own electorate, a report done by a reputable international group stated that, if the CO(2) levels were to be brought back to 1990 levels by the year 2000, and if charges were put on the various industries in such a fashion as to achieve this—that is, by the Rio type arrangements—the steel industry would be wiped out and huge damage done to the alumina industry. In my own electorate, where we rely very much on brown coal fired power stations, problems would certainly be created for that particular industry.

I say to the government sincerely and genuinely: please have in mind the effect that your carbon tax proposals have on regional Australia. This government is merely raising taxation as a matter of convenience to satisfy the moment. I have been a critic in this area for many years, both in this place and, in particular, outside. During the Fraser government period, the import parity pricing time, when fuel prices increased, I was advocating that we should look at alternative energy. Surely we should be looking at more efficient methods of using our energy? But the government—as it has illustrated by transferring the import parity pricing system across to excise in the late 1980s—cannot bring itself to provide sufficient incentives to give us an opportunity to develop alternative energies.

Yes, belatedly, we are doing something about ethanol. I welcome this and I hope that it works. But we can go so much further in this country. There is a whole range of things in this greenhouse debate and we have only touched the tip of the iceberg. We should have been at it 10, 15 and 20 years ago, because we had the capacity to do it. All it takes is a little bit of vision, planning and forethought, rather than acting on a spur of the moment situation and saying, `We have got to have some money, okay, we will raise excise, or we will put on a carbon tax.' That is my criticism in this area.

But my overriding criticism—I hope the theme comes through consistently—is the impact on regional Australia. Nowhere else but in regional Australia do you have the strongest impact of this excise. It impacts on every part of our lives. We have to use our vehicles. We do not have access to subsidised urban transport. The excise impacts upon everything: our food, entertainment, social life and cultural life. I have repeatedly pleaded with governments to consider this. It is too easy just to regard excise as a general revenue raiser.

I would like to comment about roads. As the member for Gippsland said, we are down to about eight per cent in spending on roads. I take the point that we cannot expect to have to spend $10 billion—which is the amount currently collected on roads in this country—but I can say that another two or three hundred million, on top of the $860 million that we currently spend, certainly would be most welcome in much of Australia, and particularly in regional Australia.

As far as the bicentenary project is concerned, this was a priority of the Fraser government, which recognised that roads are important to regional people, and that the infrastructure of our country is very important, as is the ability to have our commerce flow efficiently and with minimum damage. The roads are a lot better than they were 50 years ago, or even 20 years ago, and part of the reason that they are better is the bicentenary program.

Of course, if the member for Charlton were here, I would remind him about the black spot program, which was a good initiative of the Labor government. I understand that the black spot program has been abolished. Of course, we will reintroduce it. It is a recognition that, whilst you are not going to spend all of that $10 billion on roads, there is plenty of room for improvement in our road system, and we need to be more generous in the way we allocate our excise to the roads.

The honourable member for Charlton talked about rural myths. I stress that it is no myth that everything is more expensive in the bush because of the excise; I stress that there is a lack of equity in this country. We used to pride ourselves on our egalitarianism. When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was Treasurer, he had the capacity to wipe out with one blow the principle that fuel prices in regional Australia should not differ significantly from metropolitan prices. We do not respect that any more. We have made excise a convenient revenue raiser and in many cases it covers the mistakes of government in general policy. I criticise the general concept of excise being a revenue raiser. I feel very strongly about it, having had the brunt of it for 20 years under successive governments. The coalition supports the modest changes that are in place today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been interesting to listen to the debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 this morning. Everybody who participates in this debate in parliament should have an open mind and should listen to the comments of those who are very experienced in these areas, particularly in the area of fuel excise. It has been a wide-ranging debate. I am always interested to listen to the comments of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). The previous speaker, the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), acknowledged the benefits of the black spot program. Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), and I both supported this program and our electorates benefited from it.

PARA.TAB: The program was introduced by the honourable member for Charlton when he was Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support in the former Hawke government. It is interesting to note that his address this morning on this bill was the first time I have heard a government member acknowledge the increase in the excise of fuel since the Labor Party came to power in 1983—from 6c per litre to around 35c per litre today.

It was also acknowledged that the money raised was never intended to be directly related to what is spent on roads. We know that not even 10 per cent of the $10 billion-odd that is collected in excise and duty and the like is spent back on our roads. That is a line that the opposition has continually run. It is the line the shadow minister for resources and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who addressed the Main Committee this morning, and the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), have continually run. It will be good to see the honourable member for Charlton on the opposition benches reminding us of some of the debates and the comments that have been made by the frontbenchers on this side.

I reiterate that it was admitted this morning that the excise collected from fuel is collected for general revenue. It is not associated with roads and the government uses it as a drip, as a direct line from the bowser straight into the Treasury coffers for general revenue. I think it would be good if the government told the people of Australia that that is exactly what it uses those increases for.

At the last election in March 1993, the Labor Party made all sorts of promises in regard to taxation and indirect tax. Since then, we have had nothing but increases in taxation and these increases have not always been explicit.

I know this is getting off the subject but recently I was contacted by a number of people from my electorate who are dying from cancer. We have heard that the government has introduced a 21 per cent sales tax on hospital Sustagen. This is the only food that cancer sufferers, who are in a severe condition can consume, and the government has put a 21 per cent sales tax on it. This government's record, since the last election, is not very good as far as the introduction of taxes is concerned.
I return to the bill that we are discussing this morning.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—I would be very pleased if you would.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the opposition is not opposing this bill. We support these measures as they are addressing some other measures that were introduced in that 1993 budget that severely handicapped a lot of our industries in Australia, and the honourable member for Gippsland alluded to a lot of those this morning.

PARA.TAB: The bill gives effect to excise tariff proposals 2, 3 and 4 of 1994. The major amendments are: a decrease in excise duty payable on topped crude oil by 2.977c per litre to 6.586c per litre; and a decrease in excise duty on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene by 1.977c per litre to 6.586c per litre. The measures will end an anomaly applying to excise on crude oil and condensate used in the production of crude oil and condensate, reduce the rate of excise payable on aviation gasoline by 6.327c per litre and increase the excise on aviation kerosene by 1.94c per litre.

The excise tariff proposal No. 2 of 1994 proposes a decrease in the excise duty payable on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene, and a decrease in the excise duty payable on topped crude oil. These decreases were announced in the 1994 budget. The 1c per litre increase of August 1994 will not apply to topped crude oil. The decreases in excise duty on these products partly offset the 3c per litre increase in excise duty in the 1993-94 budget.

Representations from the mining and shipping industries as to the effect of the 3c per litre increase on input costs were successful in convincing the government to reduce the excise. Topped crude oil can be used as a substitute for fuel oil and the excise duties on the two oils will now be the same.

The mining industry is of vital importance to this economy today. With our atrocious overseas debt and our atrocious balance of payments figures we must look at our mining industries, our rural industries and our forestry industries to try to get this nation out of the problem that it is in. The majority of members on the government benches acknowledge that but they are not game to speak up too much, and we have not seen too much from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on these issues.

As a result of the 1993 petroleum excise increases, the major user of fuel oil in the mining industry, Nabalco, operating a bauxite mine and alumina refinery at Gove, faced an increase of its fuel oil tax bill to $30 million per year. This placed a severe burden on Nabalco's competitiveness. This is in a day and age when the government is introducing a lot of reforms. It is clearing the decks, getting ready for the World Trade Organisation to take over from the GATT agreement on 1 July this year. It is trying to get our industries as world competitive as possible, yet we are hitting them with these taxes that are really inhibiting their competitiveness on the world stage. So the government has eliminated that measure that was adopted in 1993.

The 1993 petroleum products excise increases had a particularly severe impact on the coastal shipping and mining industries, adding $9.6 million per year in cost to the shipping industry, or an average cost of $288,000 per vessel per year. This is at a time when the government's asset sale campaign was just beginning. Those asset sale committees in the Department of Finance were looking at selling ANL. On the other hand, the government is making them less competitive, less profitable. The last round of reform measures, which saw crew levels reduced to an average of 18.5 crew per vessel, delivered savings of an average of $217,000 per vessel per year, which were more than negated by the fuel excise increases.

The coalition moved amendments in the Senate which would have removed the excise increase from rail and shipping. There was considerable confusion in the vote, and Senator Margetts eventually abstained from voting, despite earlier undertakings of support from the Western Australian Greens. The coalition got considerable support from producers, transport users and the shipping and rail industries for its position.

The shipping industry has lobbied the government intensively. It has been able to demonstrate that increases such as those imposed—and they represented, in their original form, a 92 per cent increase in excise rates for that industry—were insupportable. The government has now come back and made amends for the tax increases that they put into place in 1993. And some time during the next 12 months the people of Australia will get the opportunity to pass judgment on a lot of the actions that this government has taken.
At the time that those excises were increased, the chief executive of the Australian National Maritime Association said:

SPEECH.PARA: Last night's reduction of nearly 2 cents amounts to the removal of 80% of the original cost imposition placed on shipowners at the 1993 Budget, which was originally set at 5 cents per litre. Obviously it would have been preferable for the increased excise to have been removed entirely, but the reduction is a good result worth $6.35 million per annum to shipowners. The Government clearly recognises the importance of cost-effective sea transport to Australian industry.

It did not recognise that when it introduced the thing in the first place! The proposed reductions have been received less favourably by the opposition. In a media release on 10 May 1994, the shadow minister for transport said:

While it will be of some comfort to the shipping industry that the Government has finally admitted that its imposition of fuel tax increases in the last Budget was wrong and unfair, the reduction of the excise for fuel oil in this Budget by two cents per litre still leaves the industry with costs of $96,000 per vessel per year that were wantonly imposed after the industry had struggled hard for reform gains.

The reduction represents a cut of operating costs of $196,000 per vessel per year—but nevertheless leaves the industry with having almost half of its $217,000 per vessel per year reform gains eliminated by imposed taxes.

It is a bit of a Peter and Paul situation where these taxes were introduced across the board, without serious consideration by this government as to the downstream impact on industry in Australia, especially the transport industry, which is vital to everything we do in this country.

PARA.TAB: We heard the member for Charlton this morning comparing us with the OECD countries. We continually hear the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives saying, `We are at this level' or `We are at that level' compared with other OECD countries. But can we seriously, genuinely and equitably compare our performance in this country with what goes on in all the OECD countries? We are an island continent in the Southern Hemisphere, away from the rest of the world and from the people that we trade with. We have vast distances within Australia where we have to transport domestically produced goods, produce from our farms, mines and forests. We cannot seriously make those comparisons, because we are starting off a totally different base to the other OECD countries. Although it is pretty good to use those statistics to get those comparisons, they are not genuine comparisons.

When the member for Charlton said that we are one of the lowest taxed countries in the OECD, as far as excise duty on fuel is concerned, it is not an acceptable equivalent because we are starting off totally different bases. We are very different from most other nations in what we have to do when we produce goods, how far we have to ship them and how far we have to transport them.

The next point I want to make concerns the change in the duty payable on avgas and avtur. It revolves around a major debate that has been taking place in Australia over the last two years about the operations of the Civil Aviation Authority. Every person you bump into in the street could be asked for an opinion on what should happen and how aviation safety compliance and safety regulations should be implemented by the Civil Aviation Authority, and there would be a totally different answer every time. The government has not got an answer. We saw Pontius Pilate back in the chamber yesterday and he certainly has not got an answer.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! I do not know who you are referring to as Pontius Pilate. If you are referring to a member of the House of Representatives, you will refer to that member by his proper title.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has not got the answer. We are proposing here to decrease the excise duty payable on aviation gasoline and avtur. I might just venture off that point, because we have been through exactly what the bill is going to do.

PARA.TAB: I have been involved in an inquiry which has taken evidence from a lot of people involved in general aviation. Their concern is that their businesses are being made financially unviable by the excise that they have to pay, which is supposed to be on a user-pays basis for compliance. After we took all that evidence, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts—and its report on the commercialisation of GBEs such as the CAA, which will be tabled in the parliament later this year—expressed a great deal of concern as to the operations.

We see that the government has had the ability to reduce these excises, because of efficiency gains allegedly made by the CAA in reducing its costs. How have they been reduced? There is a big question mark over the means by which the CAA has reduced those overheads, which is reduced compliance. That has been evidenced by a number of fatal accidents that are currently being inquired into by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations.

It is an area that this parliament must be very vigilant about, if we are getting these reductions because of cost savings by the CAA because of lesser compliance costs. The CAA may not be doing the job that the travelling public in Australia perceives that it is doing. There is an expectation, when someone buys a ticket on a plane, even if it is a charter flight, that that plane should be airworthy. The question remains: are the government and the CAA getting those costs down because they are not doing a full and complete job as far as compliance goes and in making sure that aircraft are airworthy, which would flow on to this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I question the relevancy of this.

—I have got only a couple of minutes left. While we are talking about the fuel excise, I will just go onto a pet subject of mine: the cost of fuel to the consumer on the mid-north coast of New South Wales. In the middle of last year, the Industry Commission completed its inquiry into the petroleum industry, and the report was handed to the minister. Over six months later, the minister still has not responded to that report.

PARA.TAB: One of the recommendations in that report was that the Prices Surveillance Authority and the government should stay right out of being involved in setting fuel price differentials and freight differentials. Two weeks ago, the Prices Surveillance Authority, which comes under the control of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), agreed to fuel freight differential increases for the oil majors.

I know only about my electorate, although I know that it affects your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, as well. Remember that, within the last fortnight, the Treasurer announced that the CPI for 1994 was 2.5 per cent. He said that part of that was because of the interest rate increases.

Why has the PSA authorised the oil companies to increase their freight charges on fuel for the mid-north coast? Port Macquarie has seen a 1.8c per litre increase in the cost of freighting motor spirit into Port Macquarie from Newcastle. Coming off a base of 2c per litre, it is now 3.8c per litre. That is an increase of 87 per cent. How on earth can anybody justify an increase of 87 per cent? The CPI last year was only 2.5 per cent, and it changes. Yet this is based on bringing fuel from Newcastle to Port Macquarie and Coffs Harbour. What happened in Coffs Harbour? Coffs Harbour went from 1.7c to 3.2c, an increase of only 1.5c per litre: it was 1.8c to Port Macquarie, and 1.5c to Coffs Harbour. I have made representations to the Assistant Treasurer and to Dr Cousins, asking them to explain what criteria they used and on what basis they have increased these costs.

There is a great disparity between the retail price of fuel on the mid-north coast of New South Wales and that in Sydney. This is only making it worse. I cannot believe that there is any logical answer to the question of allowing freight costs to increase by 87 per cent when the CPI was 2.5. I await with interest the response from the Assistant Treasurer and Dr Cousins from the PSA.

I await eagerly—as do my constituents—the government's response to the Industry Commission inquiry into the petroleum industry. That inquiry made some far-reaching recommendations, not all of which we agree with, though we certainly agree with some of them. There should be terminal gate pricing in that industry. The government and the Prices Surveillance Authority should get right out of the freight side of the petroleum industry. The Laidley agreement should be put in the bin and completely done away with.

The government lectures us about letting market forces take control. The Hilmer report on national competition has been introduced, but there is no competition. There is no competition in the freighting of fuel to the mid-north coast of New South Wales. The PSA is overseeing those sorts of unacceptable increases in this day and age, when last year's CPI was only 2.5 per cent and it has authorised an increase to Port Macquarie of 87 per cent. I look forward to a response.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Before calling the next speaker, I would like to thank the honourable member for Newcastle for his advice on relevance. I make the point that I was concentrating particularly on the content of the speech of the member for Lyons. I would caution him that, when making reference to evidence given to a joint parliamentary committee before its report is tabled, he should be careful about revealing any evidence given to that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do that.

—Good. I am just advising you of the need to exercise caution before the report is tabled. The other point I make before I call the next speaker is that this is a formal chamber of the House of Representatives and the standing orders apply here just as they do everywhere else. I remind members on both sides that standing order 56 should be followed here as well as in the main chamber.

—The issue before us today is one that was raised in the budget but, furthermore, it is a situation of this government yet again having to reverse policy because it got it wrong the first time. There has never been a more appropriate time to draw that circumstance to the attention of this chamber than at this very moment when the government is under siege from without and from within in terms of its stop-go policies on forest products.

PARA.TAB: The major aim of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) throughout his career has been to find the populist solution. He has no compunction about putting our children into massive debt to buy votes, be they from the arts community, the welfare community, or anybody else. As we well know, he has increased this parliament's debt from $15 billion to $100 billion. The documents on the budget show that his government's expenditure on public debt interest is fast approaching its expenditure on education for the very children who must pay off those debts.

If we look further into that budget, according to the government's own predictions for 1997-98 it proposes to spend in round figures $10 billion on defence, $10 billion on education and $10 billion on public debt interest. That has been the way the business has been run. That is the reason why we were informed yesterday by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that our current account deficit for this financial year will reach the staggering amount of $26 billion. We just had a record amount for the month of December of $2.4 billion.

All of this is evidenced in this legislation. There was a totally dishonest election campaign with a promise of l-a-w tax reduction. The government is now desperate to find its way through while not breaking that promise. It is looking very closely for an area in which it can raise some money to which, at least in technical terms, it did not make some specific reference during the election campaign.

Lo and behold, it got onto the old milking cow which the Prime Minister, in his days in opposition, attacked roundly when he referred to the petrol pump as becoming the tax office of Australia. He was the one who used those words and I supported his remarks at the time. The Labor Party came in and holus-bolus threw increases in fuel excise at the people of Australia without any reasonable assessment of what the effects might be.

The member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and his brother, the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), have been at the forefront in this parliament arguing the case for cabotage and arguing the case for shipping involved in our coastal services to be Australian owned. One of the effects of this tax grab was to practically put shipping out of existence, to destroy all the gains the industry had achieved by changing manning levels and trying to become efficient, remembering that the downside of any inefficient transport sector has effect across the economic board. We cannot have inefficient transport and think it affects only the workers or the investors in that industry. It dominoes through our entire industrial and economic structure.

I think it was the brother of the member for Newcastle who, when he was minister for transport, once informed the House that $1 in every $7 spent by Australians at that time was spent on transport—it may have varied somewhat since. When we throw a tax grab into transport the downside effect hits tourism, agriculture and everybody else. We saw the example recently of grain being imported at grave risk to our own industries in terms of contamination or disease. That grain was imported from the North American continent because the freight charges were cheaper from that great distance than from my state of Western Australia where we have a reasonable system. I had farmers in my electorate prepared to give grain to struggling drought affected farmers in the eastern states and the economics of getting it there destroyed the value of the gift—a pretty silly situation.

Today the government is trying to patch up another one of its mistakes. I draw the committee's attention again to the forest industry as a comparative mistake. The Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) made a decision, and I presume he made it on the best of professional environmental advice. I underline the word `professional' because we now find that money was given to people who did not even have surnames, let alone letters behind their names, which would have been a bit of a help. Just imagine it, $140,000 to Natalie and friends! I must meet Natalie. She must have some powers of persuasion. It is unbelievable!

Here we are doing the same thing today through legislation patching up. It is all comparable. It is another example of how this government flies in without any thought, without any decent proposals, grabs some money and then finds out it has damaged significant parts of the industry. We are back here today removing some of that burden that the government placed upon the shipping industry, the aviation industry and, more particularly and broadly, the transport industry.

But not only is it too little too late; it is too little. By the government's own policy yesterday, overall fuel excise went up 1/2c on its CPI proposal. On previous occasions I have drawn to the attention of the parliament the fact that this is a very silly situation because it is self-generating. I have just given evidence of how important transport is in terms of the CPI. If we inject an additional tax burden into transport by way of an adjustment of excise, the value and cost of transport increases. That goes straight into the CPI and guarantees another tax grab. That sounds ridiculous to me, particularly when the people who pay the price are the people who are trying to keep this country out of debt by producing goods that will compete with import competitors or even by going out and exporting on our behalf.

Take the case of the people who try to produce orange juice along the Murray River, in competition with people in Brazil. The Brazilians, of course, deliver to our two great markets of Melbourne and Sydney by international shipping. There is none of this fancy excise on that. International shipping buys its fuel and labour in the best markets, and is recognised as the cheapest form of transport per kilometre in the world. The Brazilians who grow orange juice get right to the front door of Melbourne and Sydney without any of those sorts of tax burdens. By comparison, our Australian producers on the Murray River—according to documentation that has been supported by the Treasury—have to pay a tax burden of $2,000 per semitrailer per week, in either these excises that we are dealing with today or the other taxes applicable to road transport, including, of course, sales tax.

So there is the situation we create for our own people. We say, `Go out and multiply, and borrow money,'—at what are now very uncertain interest rates because the Prime Minister is up to his old tricks of blowing the economy apart. He just does not seem to understand. I think that is the greatest problem we have: he does not understand. Having blown the economy apart, the government encourages these people to go out and invest for Australia. It was boasting yesterday of 24 per cent investment growth and criticising us because we said the country could not sustain 14 per cent.

That situation has not changed. The country clearly cannot sustain 14 per cent business investment growth, because we have gone to a $26 billion foreign account deficit. In other words, we could not finance that level of growth within our own economy. That was the criticism levelled at the government, and not that it could not achieve some level: you could probably achieve 50 per cent, if the government would let you borrow enough money.

I come back to the point that in this case we are telling people to invest and to develop the Australian economy; yet, through this process of excise, we load them up with financial burdens and then let their foreign competitors into the same market for nothing. I am not one who says that we should load up foreign competitors with excise or tariff burdens but, if we are going to have that so-called level playing field, I think we should not be putting onto our own people tax burdens that our overseas competitors do not pay. That is what this situation is about.

I note that the speaker who opened the case for the coalition, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), expressed continuing concern, in this same context, about the proposed carbon tax—which, of course, will just be another excise. If I can just take honourable members through the background of the carbon tax, it comes back to international conventions. A lady who has just retired from this parliament, who was minister at the time, Mrs Kelly, went rushing off to the glare of spotlights of Rio and, surrounded by greenery, stood up on the platform and with a flourish signed a foreign convention committing Australia to clean air.

There is nothing wrong with that except that the lady did not bother to read the fine print: she was too busy getting out there and gaining the publicity. The fine print says that countries will agree to bring back their emissions to 1990 levels, on a per capita basis. When we consider the size of Australia and the breezes that blow across us, we happen to have only 17.7 million people sitting over a huge land mass, with the same population, or a little less, than Taiwan—which is, by physical comparison, a postage stamp. But apparently we will now both be restricted to the same level of emissions.

Of course, energy consumption is also taxed by this excise arrangement. Energy consumption in Australia, I think, is around 215 or 250 kilojoules or whatever the measure is these days, compared—and the numbers are relevant—with something like 14 per capita in Indonesia and I think a similar figure in China. They can catch up to our 250, and we are going to have a carbon tax. We are going to say to business, `Stay in Australia; employ Australian workers and pay a carbon tax. But, of course, if you bother to transfer your business interests to Indonesia, there will be no carbon tax.' There are 120 million people in Indonesia compared with Australia's 17 million and they can consequently emit substantially more quantities of emission gases under the deal we have done with the world.

When ministers go over to conferences to sign these conventions, they leave their brains at home. Quite clearly, the application of a carbon tax or an extension of fuel excise is not in Australia's interests as an international competitor. Everything is against it—including huge distances compared with very small distances amongst our Asian competitors. The Prime Minister came back strutting his stuff and telling us what a wonderful deal he had done in Bogor—or wherever it was—on APEC. Basically, I support that principle, but I did have a question I would have liked to have asked him if he came to the parliament a little more frequently. That was: in the context of 2001 or 2010, does he expect Australia to change the Asian work ethic and the Asian economic approach or does he expect the reverse to apply. In other words, is Asia going to change us or are we going to change Asia?

As the Deputy Speaker knows, I get to the races occasionally and I would like to be running the book on that. This is the simple fact. This Prime Minister does not think about what he is doing and this legislation today is evidence of that. `Grab some money,' he told John Dawkins. Of course, John left the parliament having been fed up with taking the Prime Minister's advice and then having the Prime Minister leave him to take the blame and all the flak for the electoral dishonesty—the removal of l-a-w tax cuts. John thought he had had enough of that. He had reached the peak of his career but he did not like to have to take all that sort of burden. I thought John might have gone back into advising people on tax law, to tell you the truth, but I do not think he is; he is going to try to produce wine.

The simple facts of it are that this Prime Minister does it all the time: no proper thought, be it with forestry or the application of fuel excise, and, of course, no sensible redistribution even of that tax to infrastructure. And here we go. In my state, the state government has just had to ask for an extra 4c per litre from the people of Western Australia and that is after having put $50 on every vehicle licence in that state. But that was for a different reason. That was not the meanness of the federal government; that was to re-collect the money that Robert Holmes a Court picked up on his insurance policy of a regular donation to the Labor Party over the years.

The simple fact is that Western Australians pay $50 per vehicle licence per year because Robert Holmes a Court walked into the then state Labor government and convinced it, through the State Government Insurance Commission, to use $850 million of the public's resources to buy assets that were unsaleable at that time and upon which $450 million was lost. But Holmes a Court had been a regular donor to the Labor Party; it was time to call up his creditors and they responded overnight. In fact, it is amazing when we read the papers to see how frequently John Holland Constructions, now the property of Mrs Holmes a Court, gets government contracts, particularly here and overseas. I see she got another one the other day.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is also time to return to the bill.

—With respect to the bill, I am sure Mrs Holmes a Court's companies use quite a bit of excisable fuel so, on that side of it, she would be welcoming my remarks, but she probably would not be welcoming the others. I get a bit browned off when I see her name being floated for Australian of the Year when every penny that she has in her business was donated by Western Australian taxpayers per favour of the then Labor governments that were running our state. Those governments destroyed our economy and destroyed more the credibility of Western Australians. We were looked upon as a mob of crooks when in fact it was only a small group in cooperation with the then Labor governments.

PARA.TAB: Let me come back to the specifics. This legislation has been introduced by the government to correct a mistake. That particular mistake was to attack, in its tax grab, our very vulnerable coastal shipping industry and our more vulnerable mining industry. That industry was using fuel oil as the main source of energy at Nabalco. These sorts of issues should have been thought through, just as the forestry industry issue should have been thought through before this government opened its mouth.

But we have a Prime Minister who just waits for the polls and tries to address them either by borrowing money, which our kids have to repay, and then spending it or, in this case, trying to have two bob each way between the forest industry and the greens. He seems to have dissatisfied both of those groups, which is not surprising considering, as I said, he went and took advice from people who do not have surnames, let alone the sorts of qualifications and experience that one would expect them to have when deciding such a serious issue. Remember: every log that Australia does not produce will be produced by other less environmentally controlled parts of the world, and that is even more concerning. However, that does not worry the Prime Minister; his thought processes are too narrow.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Each of the speakers I have listened to in this debate has talked about international competitiveness. The minister, when proposing these amendments, spoke about international competitiveness. I have based my remarks today on international competitiveness. We are, allegedly, reducing the costs to business by reducing these charges and that will help to make these businesses more internationally competitive.

PARA.TAB: In addressing the point of international competitiveness, I say in this place, and I have said this on numerous occasions almost everywhere I have had the opportunity to speak, that it is about time that we in this country understood the nature of our non-competitiveness. Every four years, in recent Australian history, mining growth has been 25 per cent and agricultural growth has hovered around 15 per cent. In the last four years mining growth has shrunk from 25 per cent to 3.6 per cent and farming growth has shrunk from 13 per cent—arguably, 15 per cent—to 1.9 per cent. So the juggernauts, the locomotives of the Australian economy, are stopping dead in their tracks.

The problems in mining, which centre around land rights, greenies and those sorts of things, are not the subject of this debate, but the agricultural issues most certainly are. The cost of fuel is one of the four major cost input items for farmers. Ninety-three per cent of this nation's income comes from primary production and mining. Wherever I go I carry the list of our export earning items for anyone who wants to see it. The remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that this country is now a manufacturing country are deceitful in the extreme.

If the Prime Minister is quoting different figures, he is obviously interpreting such enterprises as meatworks as being an industrial undertaking rather than a primary production, which is quite valid in one sense, but if the agricultural sector is not growing then most certainly the processing side of the agricultural sector will be dying as well. That is the more relevant statistic.

In speaking about our non-competitiveness, I point out that the first of the five major cost items for agriculture in order of priority—and that tells a story—is interest rates. Interest rates for our farmers are around 12.5 per cent at the moment. Our biggest competitor is the United States, where interest rates are half of that, at six per cent. Our second cost item is labour, and the last figures I saw were $4 per hour labour costs in the United States while in Australia our labour costs are $8 an hour. I am corrected because the most recent industrial award in Queensland puts them up to $11.50, I am told.

In Queensland, the cost input item in Queensland which is third in order of priority and size is water. This may not be true for other states. The cost of water in California, the biggest agricultural producing state in the United States, is $3.90. In Queensland it is $30, nearly 1,000 per cent difference. With regard to fertilisers, in the United States, urea was $203 a tonne the last time I looked, and in Australia it is $396 a tonne.

The most relevant statistic in this debate is fuel costs. I carry with me wherever I go—for anyone who wants to see it—a copy of the 1982 speech in the Opera House before the election of the Labor government when the quite unequivocal promise was made that the government would restrain inflation by reducing the price of petrol in Australia by 2c a litre. Since this government has been in power and that promise was made, the take by the federal government went from 22.7c per litre up to 31.8c per litre in 1991. I imagine that another 3c would have been added to that by now, which would bring it to 34c per litre.

So instead of reducing the price of oil by 2c per litre the Prime Minister has increased the price by 12c per litre. I therefore back up the remarks of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) who reminded us that the present Prime Minister coined the famous phrase that the then government was turning every petrol bowser attendant into a tax collector. Mr Keating has, in fact, done that very thing in a magnificent manner.

In a debate about the cost of oil in Australia in its various forms, I cannot but point out that, in a country where distance counts for so much, not only has this government increased our cost structure by imposing this huge discriminatory tax on fuel but also, even more reprehensibly, it has allowed the oil companies to increase their take. One must remember that at the same time the world price of oil has dropped clean in half the price the Australian oil companies charge the retailers for oil has doubled. So whilst the cost of purchasing the oil has halved, the price they are selling it at has doubled. In that time frame, there has been one small upgrading of one refinery in Queensland, and that has been the only capital outlay by the oil companies in Australia in the last decade. Their productivity cost increases have been virtually nil. All of them have cut back on the number of employees and yet they have doubled their take.

This a lot of money that we are talking about here. Their take in 1983 was 12.8c per litre and their take in 1993 was 23.4c per litre. Also, they picked up another 10.2c per litre because of the reduction in the world price. This gave them a whacking 20.8c per litre which they are not entitled to. They are not entitled to one single cent. Twenty cents per litre translates into $5.7 billion per year which they are creaming off from the Australian public and to which they are not entitled.

Whilst I regard the tax impositions of the federal government as reprehensible in the extreme for increasing our cost structures in Australia, I also have to make the point that even more reprehensible has been the government's failure to act against the oil companies of Australia, which have taken profits which are unconscionable. Not only are they unconscionable but they make us, internationally, non-competitive.

Yesterday the biggest monthly current account deficit in Australian history was announced. One would think that, because every month now $2 billion more goes out of this country than comes into this country, it is a problem that needs addressing. The ramifications of it are very serious. The year before last, interest on the federal government debt was $3.9 billion and the year after next the interest will be $9.1 billion. That is a huge leap and a huge cost imposition upon the Australian public. But it is going to get a lot worse because if you are trading at a loss of $2 billion a month then your debt is skyrocketing and feeding upon itself.

The policy instituted by `Placido Domingo', our wonderful and glorious leader, for the control of the current account deficit, is to create a recession. His famous remark that `This is the recession we had to have' was a clear-cut statement of his approach to the economy. It staggers me that such a woefully ignorant economic statement can be made in this place, particularly given the scrutiny of the media.

The media has lauded the government. Also, a lot of my political supporters have said to me, `You must admit that they have controlled inflation'. I agree with them that this is the greatest drop in inflation in Australian history. `Placido Domingo' has achieved the greatest restraint on inflation and decrease in the consumer price index in Australian history. In fact, there has only been one other period in Australian history when inflation has been restrained along these lines. That point in our history was 1930—the Depression. The opposite of inflation is depression.

What you see in Australia today is an horrific depression which has cost 1.5 million Australians their jobs and has cost 800,000 small businessmen and farmers their businesses. When you increase interest rates and you have a government imposed recession upon the Australian economy—the mechanism by which we control the current account deficit—the cost out there is so enormous that it overrides any other consideration.

Ted Theodore was described by Manning Clark as the most intelligent person to ever set foot in this place. Mind you, at times I do not know whether he has very much competition. When Theodore wrote to Curtin in reply to a letter from Curtin requesting him to take over the running of the Australian economy during the war, which he did subsequently, Theodore said the most important government task was to provide work for the people.

I commend John Langmore for his very excellent book Work for All, where he reiterates exactly the same theme, that the most important function of government is to enable people to have a sense of pride, a place of work, a value in the community and income to look after their families. When that does not occur we have a situation such as in Australia today, where we have the highest juvenile suicide rate in the entire world. In Queensland we recorded in one year what has to be the highest increase in juvenile crime in the world—a 30 per cent increase.

That is the price that is being paid out there for the heartbreak of a nation, where one in three kids cannot get a job and where nearly a million Australian business families have gone broke. Not only have they lost everything; they walk away from their businesses with a debt over their head. Very few of them take bankruptcy; they just walk away. There is still a debt over their head. They will work for the rest of their lives to repay it, if they ever make any money. The bank will foreclose on them and try to get back its money, which has been increasing because interest has been applied to that debt which has not been repaid.

Let me be very specific. Not only has the Prime Minister said that this is the recession that we had to have, but the figures clearly indicate that he is correct. Unemployment rose from six per cent in 1986 to 11.3 per cent in 1992-93. Bankruptcies rose from about 6,000 in 1986 to 16,000 in the early 1990s. That was the cost that we paid for restraining the current account deficit.

Here today we are making a very small effort—but I praise the government for at least making some effort, however small and insignificant it might be—to restrain the costs of production. I go back to the figures that the economy depends upon in mining and agriculture.
