Agriculture cannot compete where its cost structures are between 50 and 1,000 per cent higher than those of our nearest competitor. I am talking about cost structures; I am not addressing the subsidies. I know that in wheat the European subsidy is about 100 per cent and in sugar it is 193 per cent. So two of our seven biggest export items are competing against subsidies of between 100 and 193 per cent. That does not encompass the fact of the difference in cost structures.
Of those cost structures, the cost of money—interest rates—is set by the government. Let there be no doubt about that. It is something that the Prime Minister has said on numerous

SPEECH.PARA: occasions and that the Reserve Bank has skited about on numerous occasions. It is true, they control interest rates. The cost of money is controlled by the government. The cost of labour in Australia, which I am proud is very, very high, is also a cost set by government. The farmer cannot do anything about it. The third cost, the cost of water, is a cost set by government. The farmer cannot do anything to control the price of the water that he gets. So we have government imposed cost structures.

PARA.TAB: Half of the price of petrol goes to the government, so the government controls half of the price, because it has not moved against the oil companies. We are being taken to the cleaners to the tune of $6,000 million a year by the oil companies. Those figures I quoted are from the breakdown of the costs and prices in the oil industry from 1982 to 1992, by the Australian Institute of Petroleum.

Finally, on the issue of the decrease in these price structures, I want to address very specifically the issue we are talking about here—the cost of running the aviation industry in Australia. We people representing country electorates are told that we must accept the principle of user pays and the great philosophy which has become known as the level playing field. One of the great elements and pillars that prop up the structure and the philosophy of the level playing field is the concept of user pays.

What that translates to is that Brisbane gets an international airport, costing some $600 to $700 million, to service overseas people or Australians that want to leave Australia. Brisbane gets a $700 million golden handshake. Mount Isa, which produces $1,200 million of revenue every single year for Australia—and is suffering greatly because it is not running at a profit, and has not been for some years—loses just about everything that one saw when one went to the airport. The fire brigade tender has been removed, which is very dangerous, of course; it would be nearly seven miles to town and the nearest fire brigade, should there be any problems out there. The control tower has been removed completely. All of the staff have been removed from there. The maintenance gang which was responsible for servicing the airstrip has been removed. The Qantas services to Mount Isa—Qantas being a government owned instrumentality—have been removed from Mount Isa totally; half of its services have gone.

So the level playing field means a $700 million golden handshake for Brisbane, the international tourists and people who want to leave Australia and have enough money to go cavorting around the world. But the poor old worker in Mount Isa finds himself in grave danger every time he tries to land at the airport in Mount Isa, or uses what is left of the air services that go into Mount Isa.

The constitution is very clear-cut on this. Aviation is a function of the federal government, not of the state government or of local governments. I fought tenaciously to have my own cabinet, during the some six years I was in it, say to the federal government, `We will refuse to take over a single, solitary airstrip. The constitution enables us to refuse to take them over. Let any death that occurs on an airstrip in Australia be upon your head.'

Our airstrips are falling to pieces, as our little communities cannot bring in their rates because of the collapse of the rural communities. One in four farmers has left the land since 1986, crushed and destroyed by the policies of this government. They were internationally non-competitive because of cost structures imposed by this government.(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Since my second reading speech, only two speakers have spoken to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994. They were the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who have addressed the issues on what is a narrow, technical tax bill. But we have allowed a wide-ranging debate, and have discussed a whole range of issues, covering virtually every activity of federal, state and local government. The fact is that this bill proposes a reduction in tax, in the case of the excise tariff proposal No. 2 by some $25 million per year. In the case of excise tariff proposals Nos. 3 and 4, the financial impact is neutral.

PARA.TAB: Since 10 a.m. this morning—for the last two hours—we have had a succession of opposition speakers dealing with virtually every subject except the bill before this chamber. I do not intend to respond to any of the matters that were raised by the members, apart from what the member for Gippsland had to say with respect to the way in which excise duty is raised through the Commonwealth parliament.

He knows, as I do, that excise duty is a tax-raising device which is set out in the Australian constitution. The only way in which we can change the methodology of raising funds to support government expenditure is through the authority of the constitution. To vary that methodology or process, one needs to change the constitution. I simply respond to his challenge to me of this morning by suggesting to him that we do not intend, at this stage, to put to the people an amendment to change the constitution with respect to the tax-raising powers of this parliament. Indeed, these amendments go to the Excise Tariff Act of 1921—of 74 years ago. Federal parliament has since operated under that regime with respect to the imposition of excises and so forth.

As the member for Charlton says, Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is in response to initiatives announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the last budget. The initiatives came into effect from midnight on the day the budget was presented, and this legislation is simply to put in place, under legislative authority, the initiatives which were introduced by the Treasurer. There is nothing more to be said on this issue, and I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Lindsay)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost sad, in a way, to have the opportunity to speak to this important paper on Australian investment in South-East Asia, dealing with Australia's trade potential in Asia, at a time when we are witnessing in this great country such devastating economic reports on what is wrong with the management of this country. It is hard to focus on Australia's potential, to keep up morale, to encourage Australian people to invest and to take risks domestically, and to win export markets overseas when we see evidence almost daily of the problems created by the federal government. This government has virtually run Australia for 12 years, mostly with state governments of the same political persuasion, although, fortunately, in the last couple of years, that has changed dramatically. We on this side hope that the situation will continue to change.

PARA.TAB: I will chronicle some of the problems that are huge impediments to the ability of people in this country to pick up Australia's potential in respect of Asia—potential which is highlighted in the report which is the subject of discussion today.

The current account deficit figures for December, which were released yesterday, are absolutely chilling. The amount of the deficit is almost $25 billion, the highest recorded in Australia's history. Accompanying the announcement is a belated indication by the government that the forthcoming budget will be a horror budget. Since its election in 1993, the government has had the opportunity to pull levers correctly for economic management in Australia. However, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in an extraordinary comment—almost an aside—during question time this week, in the absence of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), announced the forthcoming horror budget.

The government has given a confused indication to the markets, and to Australians generally, about what is likely to happen to interest rates. It now seems likely that, when the Prime Minister contradicted the Treasurer and said that interest rates will not rise in the near future, the Prime Minister was incorrect. The Treasurer, in an attempt to be honest with the Australian people and to tell the truth about why the markets are now so overheated, hinted that interest rates will rise. The government is in panic and disarray, and is unable to agree on fundamental policies. The Treasurer foreshadowed that, in May—believe it or not, a statement will be made in May, rather than now—the government intends to make clear to Australians certain changes to the economic management of the nation. These changes will involve new taxes, including new indirect taxes, and other measures by the government in an effort to try to change the direction in which we have been heading since the present government was re-elected in 1993.

Now that is just not good enough. How can Australians gain a foothold of worth in Asia and be encouraged to take risks and invest over there if their domestic base is threatened by this sort of mismanagement by the government. It is good to see that the government's former minister for industry, the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), is going to participate in this debate. He must feel heavy at heart—if he could speak frankly in this debate. He knows about the potential Australians have to win export markets and improve our balance of trade. But he also knows that the bottom line is that there has to be a domestic base to do that. If the proper government atmospherics and management are not there, how on earth can Australian business people possibly persuade shareholders, bankers and financiers to make the necessary huge commitments that are involved, let alone do so themselves.

All Australian wealth makers—those in business and industry, small, medium and large—are being asked to continue to make investments to win trade in Asia at a time when they do not know the sorts of taxes they are going to face. They do not know what is going to happen with interest rates, except that it is very likely that they are going to continue to rise—and they have already risen almost 50 per cent in the last six months. They know that the Commonwealth government has forced states, local government and business to curtail spending and borrowing due to the worst recession Australia has had for 60 years, which was forced by the government, in a panic situation, causing hardship to a lot of people. They know that all those sacrifices that were made during that time by small businesses that were lost and forced into bankruptcy were not worth it. And it seems that we are now going to go into another period of uncertainty, pain and lost opportunity. That is just not good enough.

As I walked through the timber workers, with their continuing protest today—as all members would have—I felt very angry about the loss of opportunities. Those are decent people. Sure, they have got vested interests: their jobs, their families, their investments. Those guys are trying to pay $20,000 a month on their rigs. They have mortgaged their homes to get the banks and the financial institutions to lend the money to allow them to operate those rigs. They have got vested interests, sure—but nothing to be apologising to anyone about.

Those guys made their investments because the federal government assured Australians before the last election that they could invest in the timber industry, that there was going to be a national timber strategy, that the controversial, delicate and sensitive decisions about where forestry activities could and could not be carried out, and what could and could not be chipped, would be made in an organised, responsible way that everyone would respect. But what we find, under our very noses in Australia, is that the government that says, `Go out into Asia. Take all the opportunities that present themselves' cannot even come up with the right processes to handle an issue as important and strategic, but yet as fundamentally simple, as that. If the government is a manager, why can it not manage issues like that?

The reason it cannot is that the Labor Party in Australia is made up of too many vested interests. It is paralysed and incapable of making the proper strategic judgments because it has sold itself off. The government is now faced with threatened resignations by five important regional members of the parliamentary Labor Party. A senator has already resigned in Tasmania, for different—but related—reasons. And there is more to come.

Also, if the operating of our timber industry in Australia is done properly, it is going to help us reduce our current account deficit. If we get it right, we can reduce the amount of imported supplies from the timber industry that we need every day because we have got a shortfall. What do we find? Right between our eyes, we find a government that from December has paralysed the timber industry in Australia at a time when it was trying to get our balance of trade right in its industry. The industry was trying to become self-sufficient, to reduce the amount that we have to sell off oversea to buy back value added in the form of wood-chipping and to become sustainable. I think the government's performance is disgraceful.

The matter relates to the report. My friend the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) is correctly showing me the report and saying, `What about talking on the report?' I want to be honest here today and say, `What is the good of talking about a worthwhile report when your own government cannot even manage the domestic situation correctly?' It has an impact on our ability to take advantage of those things.

Our friends in Asia, some of whom are very shrewd people, make assessments about whether they want to do joint ventures with us. The report contains indications of how we are going to be able to take advantage of these situations. Most of the situations in Asia are going to have to be on a joint venture basis because the people there are very pragmatic. They want to keep their own ownership intact and to encourage people to come in and invest but not sell off. I have got no real objection to that, I might add. I wish we did more of that in Australia, but we are so short of capital we are going to be driven more and more to allowing foreign ownership of more and more of our Australia, which is a hell of a pity from my point of view. Maybe if we can get enough wealth going we will be able to buy some of our own farm back in Australia, but to do that we have got to have successful investments overseas as well.

The astute Asian governments and investors and businessmen are looking askance at Australia. They like us—sure, they like us—but they are looking and saying, `If you guys from Australia are going to take a share in what we are going to do over here together, how do we know you are going to be able to sustain it? Your financing of this enterprise, that you say you will put forward in conjunction with your bankers and investors and all that, is predicated on the basis that your domestic base, which is the important part in the philosophy of building Australia's industry potential, is sound. If your financial security is threatened because the government does not know how to run the economy and manage it properly, you can be brought undone.'

Even the great Australian company BHP would say today that it can do a lot of things itself and do very, very well. It has pretty good managers and they have done a lot of great things in the last 10 years to make massive changes and win markets overseas. A lot of their strategies at the highest level are predicated on their domestic health—their domestic base. If the domestic base in the economy is threatened, how on earth can we sustain activities overseas? That is the crucial point that I wanted to make today in respect of this report.

I want to say something else. I am a member of the trade committee of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. We are about to commence an inquiry into the potential of services exports into Asian countries. In Australia, we have discovered that our share of services exports to Asia and other countries is very low. In fact, we export only about five per cent of our total services activities. Most of the Asian countries that we are dealing with are already involved in economies such as Hong Kong, where 80 per cent of the economy, which is a vast economy as you know, is made up of services activities.

We recognise the potential of services. We propose to have a look at two countries in particular as part of our inquiry into the potential services exports. One of them is Indonesia and the other one is Hong Kong. We will look at Hong Kong particularly because of the impending changes in 1997 and the strengthening of the opportunity to enhance Australia's prospects of gaining services investments from Australia into the great economy of China, which will dominate the world economies in the next century without a doubt.

In the briefings with my colleagues on the committee before we start our inquiry—which has been advertised, and we are looking forward to many submissions to it—I was interested to learn that we are in a very strong position in Indonesia to take advantage of their growing demands, in the services areas particularly. This is because Indonesia is going through dramatic changes where the deregulation of banking and financial services is under way. They are already starting to lower some of the barriers—as other Asian countries are examining doing, as well.

One of the complaints we all get from Australian people trying to win markets overseas is that they are blocked off by barriers that are put around the countries that we are trying to get into. One of the big challenges that the report highlights, and which I think we will have to be very good at, is negotiating with these countries appropriate relaxation of those barriers. That involves an enormous amount of work and skill, in the meantime, to get our people out and about in these countries to take advantage of the opportunities that are opening up every day. They are very exciting challenges, but I only wish I could say that the people willing to take those challenges were supported by a federal government that could do the job for them. It cannot do that. Quite frankly, we need a change of government.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to endorse at least some of the comments and contribution of the last several minutes of the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) and wish his inquiry all the very best in terms of its aims and objectives. I come to this debate with limited preparation, having found out only yesterday that the matter was on the books and that it would be a good idea if I contributed. So I burnt the midnight oil—and quite a bit also this morning—and read the report, trying to come to terms with the many complex issues which are part of it.

PARA.TAB: The report itself is interesting and very thought provoking. It addresses a number of Australian public perceptions that are apparently inaccurate regarding the situation within South-East Asia. It provides sound, constructive and realistic recommendations as to what may be done. To an extent, it has been hamstrung by a limited amount of data and the small sample that was used in the case studies that were done; but the nature of that small sample is significant, particularly given the fact that the report shows that the number of companies investing in South-East Asia is not as great as it should be.

The report comes as a result of a meeting of the Standing Committee of Deputy Secretaries on East Asia, which directed the East Asia Analytical Unit to undertake a study regarding these issues. In July 1993, the Trade and Investment Forum of the National Trade Strategy consultative process endorsed the project. The formal terms of reference, which I put on record, were:

SPEECH.PARA: -to document the flow of investment into South-East Asia during the 1980s and Australia's relative share of that inflow; identifying trends, countries and sectors of major activity

-to survey the existing literature on the relationship between trade and investment, and on the factors influencing companies' investment decisions, with particular reference to the South-East Asia experience
-to further analyse survey data collected on Australian business activities in South-East Asia with particular reference to industry-specific investment activities
-to discuss the outlook for investment opportunities and to assess the implications for Australia in foreign investment strategies.

It is also clear from the acknowledgments that the staff of the unit—in particular, Pamela Fayle, who is the secretary—should be congratulated for the work they have done. Congratulations are also in order for work done by Luttrell Consulting Services, Business International Australia and a range of businesses that were involved in completing surveys and in being case studies, and also to officials from Foreign Affairs and Trade, Treasury, Transport and Communications, PM&C, Austrade, EFIC and the Bureau of Industry Economics.

PARA.TAB: As I said, they have come up with quite a comprehensive report which details the situation regarding Australian investment in South-East Asia and also some of the perceptions of the way that has operated over the years. South-East Asia is normally seen as the ASEAN countries—Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, Philippines and Thailand—but the report also refers to Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

First, I will focus on some of the perceptions that I think are generally held within Australia—I have certainly held them at times—which this report addresses. I have always thought it was the case that there was large-scale Australian investment, certainly over the last decade or two, in South-East Asia. I was surprised to find from the report that this is not so. The figures covering the period 1981 to 1991—comparing levels of Australian direct investment for various overseas areas, and showing the levels in Australian dollars, and the percentage of overseas investment that those amounts represent—show a very different picture.

Within those Asian countries in 1981 the figure was $A1,774 million, which was the equivalent of 38.9 per cent of our overseas investment at that time. Ten years later, in 1991, the figure was only $1,635 million. However, given the overall increase that occurred in foreign investment, and obviously the change in Australia dollar values over that time, that represents only 4.5 per cent of Australian investment overseas. That represents, over time, a net decrease annually of one per cent.

This contrasts dramatically with investments to the UK which went from $469 million or 10.3 per cent in 1981 to $13,916 million or 38.7 per cent in 1991, an increase of 40.4 per cent. The same can be said for the United States, in terms of similar growth, and also New Zealand. But the question in South-East Asia was that that was not the case. The figures that have come through for the year June 1991 to June 1992 show an encouraging 25 per cent growth. It is only one year and, as such, it is not a huge sample, but it is a good sign that that matter has been corrected.

Another issue which I think has been of some concern within Australia over the years is overseas investment, by definition, taking jobs from Australia or stopping jobs being created in Australia. Offshore investment can drive trade and exports. The East Asia Analytical Unit's 1992 survey of Australian firms which invest in South-East Asia showed that 90 per cent of Australian investors were sourcing inputs from Australia. However, only one-third were sourcing more than 50 per cent of inputs from Australia. There is a capacity to link back to Australia and that capacity will vary according to the nature of the investment, the nature of the productive activity undertaken. That shows that when people invest overseas it can, and often will, result in investment back to Australia in a way that will assist the Australian economy.

Three general effects that relate to this overall condition are export generating effects, import generating effects and export displacement effects. With respect to export generating effects, the general view is that additional sales of finished goods, components, raw materials and capital equipment will occur. They will occur on the basis that overseas operations that are set up will require assistance from the host company in Australia in the development of the overseas operations. Also, as the overseas economy that is being invested in grows, the market there will generally become more lucrative and larger. That will lead to greater demand for imports to that country and, hopefully, our share of exports from Australia.

Import generating effects can also occur. This can relate to the foreign subsidiary exporting back to Australia with a finished product. This can still lead to profit return to Australia, by the overseas subsidiary returning its profit to Australia. There are also export displacement effects where a foreign subsidiary may replace exports from Australian factories in other overseas markets. I guess the question is whether that would have occurred anyway.

There has been a lot of concern, and I am certainly one who has been concerned, about the question of job losses within Australia and the movement of some companies overseas. I think that has enormous impact on particular regions and communities and on the people that that actually affects. However, I still think we have to ask ourselves that hard question about whether this would have occurred anyway.

Are we in a situation, with the increased internationalisation of the economy, whereby some activities that have become essentially uncompetitive in Australia would have gone anyway? Are we in a situation where it is perhaps better, if it is the only choice available, that an Australian firm operating through an overseas subsidiary picks up that work rather than it being lost in total to any aspect of the Australian economy?

Another question which relates to that is the question of profit repatriation. The argument often is that investments overseas do not return anything like what they should to the Australian economy. Of the case studies undertaken, only five of the 18 case studies sent less than 75 per cent of their profits back to Australia, and several were repatriating 100 per cent.

As I said, investment can be successful and have benefits for Australia. I would like to profile the Ansell company, which is presently on the edge of my electorate but will be in the middle of the electorate I will be contesting at the next election. There is a case study in the report which I would like to read from. It is headed `Profile of an Australian company investing in South East-Asia', and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ansell International is an excellent example of a company which saw an investment opportunity in South-East Asia and proceeded to develop it to obtain a leading share in the world market for its main products.

It then goes through the history of the company, from 1905. What were the factors which led Ansell to choose Malaysia as the base for its initial investment? The principle reason was ready access to the supply of the essential raw material, rubber latex. Other factors included: reliable electricity supplies, the availability of a water supply, a suitable local work force, incentives offered by the host government and the absence of an import licensing regime. Malaysia required only 20 per cent local equity in the Ansell project, and that condition has been relaxed in recent years. Infrastructure was available and has since been considerably upgraded. The case study goes on to state:

Ansell's decision to locate its first overseas factory in Malaysia was the product of a considerable planning period, during which the positive factors were weighed against relative factors, such as: risk to capital, delay in receiving a return on the funds, and an unfamiliar business environment.
The company also assessed the political situation in each of the countries under consideration and had discussions with the (then) Departments of Foreign Affairs and Overseas Trade.

The result has been a reduction in Australia's imports (of rubber latex) and new exports of raw materials, machinery, parts and services such as training. For Malaysia, there has been an increase in employment and a substantial increase in the operating capital of the country.

Ansell has shown, as some other companies have, that it can be successful operating in the South-East Asian area. But, as I have said, when one looks at those investment figures one has to worry about the question of whether that view is getting through to the rest of the Australian business community.

PARA.TAB: Through the survey, a number of reasons were given for not investing offshore in the area. They include: the argument that it is riskier than the domestic market; the fact that the company was still seeking the right opportunity; difficulties of business culture; difficulty in obtaining finance; and lack of business contacts offshore.

EMPHASIS.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.30 p.m. to 12.41 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the limited amount of time available to me after the division, I will turn straight to the recommendations of the report and paraphrase them as best I can. They are quite detailed, they are quite specific in the action that they suggest and they are practical in terms of their application. That is important regarding trying to address the opportunities that exist in South-East Asia.

PARA.TAB: The first point may be paraphrased as better information. There needs to be more work done to ensure that commercial bodies and business have more and better information about what is available for them regarding assistance and what is the actual situation they face in South-East Asian markets. The survey noted the fact that many business people had perceptions as to the state of play in a particular market, but the detail and experience of recent years, in particular, showed that those perceptions were incorrect. Certainly that was the information provided by the firms which were operating in those areas. One interesting aspect was that a number of participants had not accessed government information services—the embassy, DFAT—so were essentially not fully on top of what was occurring in those areas and therefore were operating under an illusion.

A lot more work can be done through Austrade, through industry associations and through national trade investment outlook conferences to ensure that that situation is remedied, to make sure that people are in a position to understand the markets they are looking at and to realise that the markets are nowhere near as scary as many potential investors seem to believe. Better networking also is a key aspect of what needs to occur. There is not enough networking going on between Australian firms, even in terms of overseas joint ventures, as the honourable member for Indi alluded to earlier. More work needs to be done in terms of developing those linkages and putting the people into a situation where they can maximise the advantages available to them on the question of networking the local areas.

There is also the question of finetuning Australia's advantages. There is a range of issues in terms of micro-economic reform and improvements in infrastructure which need to continue to occur. We need also to ensure that the advances that we have made are well known within that region, so that people there can understand that there is a value for them to recognise. As a trade investment partner and also in terms of work force skills, education and training, technological capacity and research and development, we have a number of natural advantages that could be used to greater effect within the region. Again there are consultative processes and conferences that can be utilised and it is recommended under this process that we use them.

Another problem is the question of a lack of reliable and detailed statistics regarding the situation in the region. The Australian Bureau of Statistics and other organisations need to work together to make sure we have reliable information to ensure that the opportunities in trade and investment in South-East Asia are maximised. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Nehl) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will NETTFORCE approve training programs under the training wage system.
(2) Are NETTFORCE approvals subject to the final approval of State training authorities.
(3) What progress has been made in establishing agreements with each State on the relationship between NETTFORCE and State training authorities.
(4) With which States have agreements been established.
(5) How will the cost of establishing the training wage system be shared between the Commonwealth and the States.
(6) Have all States agreed to the cost-sharing arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) NETTFORCE can provide "interim" approval of training packages under the National Training Wage Award. Clause 7 of the Award—Definitions—states that a traineeship means a system of training which has been approved by the relevant State or Territory Training Authority, or which has been approved on an interim basis by the National Employment and Training Taskforce (NETTFORCE), until final approval is granted by the relevant State or Territory Training Authority.
(2) NETTFORCE "interim" approval of training packages is subject to the final accreditation by State and Territory Training Authorities.

(3) NETTFORCE has approached all State/Territory Training Authorities requesting them to enter into agreements to define the roles and responsibilities of each organisation and to develop a constructive working relationship. The negotiations go to such matters as the streamlined administration of training, including client responsiveness performance standards.

(4) NETTFORCE is negotiating with all States and Territories. Agreements have now been signed with Queensland and New South Wales and are finalised and ready for signature with Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Discussions are continuing with South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory.

(5) Entry level training under the National Training Wage Award (NTWA) will continue under the existing cost-sharing parameters between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. The Commonwealth is providing funding through ANTA for off-the-job training costs for trainees (following agreement by the ANTA Ministerial Council in 1993).

The White Paper announced targets for additional trainees and provided additional funding to meet half the costs of off-the-job training associated with these trainees. The growth funding the Commonwealth is providing to ANTA can also be used.
On-the-job training is to be funded by individual employers, as is presently the case.

(6) Discussions are also proceeding between my Department and individual State and Territory Training Authorities about agreement for processing and monitoring Training Wage agreements. Agreements have been signed with Queensland and finalised with New South Wales. The remainder are due to be completed over the next few weeks subject to receipt of proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: Is the Australian Electoral Commission initiating a household numbering system for all federal electoral divisions; if so, when will households in the division of Wannon which are not assigned a household number be converted to the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Electoral Commission is not initiating a Rural Property Numbering system. However, for some years it has been supporting the concept of numbering rural properties based on their distance from a fixed point (usually the start of the road).

Rural property numbering gives advantages to property owners through better provision of emergency and other services and for deliveries and personal visits. The AEC is interested because better numbering has the capacity to significantly increase the accuracy of the electoral roll.

Although there are electoral benefits, property numbering is properly the responsibility of local governments which control funding and timetables. However, I note that in New South Wales it is currently being sponsored by DEET as a job creation project.
The Australian Electoral Commission's past support has taken several forms:
preparation of an instruction manual for those local government areas that want to do the work themselves;
seminars, instructional sessions and some preliminary field work training for those who are carrying out the task;

sample numbering to show local government authorities how the concept works and to build Electoral Commission expertise. Some sample numbering has taken place on the Princes Highway and on the Cobden/Port Campbell Road in the Division of Wannon;
research work with a number of local government bodies to find the best and cheapest ways to do the field work; and participation in groups working to further the concept.
